title: France keeps up its pressure on the EU's AI Act, despite mounting criticism
summary: Although EU member-states are being asked to ratify the European regulation bill, Paris has pointed out 'a few points that still appear to us to raise problems,' particularly concerning intellectual property rights.

title: The mirage of normalization between Israel and Saudi Arabia
summary: The US swears by a rapprochement between the two regional powers as a peaceful solution to the Palestinian question, even though the war has hardened Middle Eastern views and government positions.

title: Macron's peaceful visit to India, a world away from French farmers' wrath
summary: Most of the president's trip on Thursday and Friday, January 25 and 26, was intended to be ceremonial, even at the risk of appearing out of step with the tense situation in France.

title: Japanese TV networks struggle to acknowledge sexual assaults by their stars
summary: In a country where the #MeToo movement has remained limited in scope, the TV networks –  though they are usually quick to 'cancel' any celebrity arrested for drug possession – have long remained silent about sex scandals involving their presenters.

title: World's largest cruise ship sets sail from Miami
summary: Royal Caribbean's 'Icon of the Seas' can carry up to 7,600 passengers at maximum capacity, the population of a small city.

title: Nazi death camp survivors gather on 79th anniversary of Auschwitz liberation
summary: Nearly 6 million Jews were killed by the Nazis during World War II. Observances were also held in many other countries on Saturday.

title: In Brazil, the battle for São Paulo is on
summary: The left has set its sights on the economic capital, trying to unseat the right in the upcoming municipal elections in October. Its young candidate, strongly backed by Lula, is considered the favorite against the scandalous current mayor.

title: Australian Open: Sabalenka crushes Zheng in women's final
summary: Belarusian champion Aryna Sabalenka dominated Chinese challenger Zheng Qinwen in a 76-minute rout, claiming her second Grand Slam crown.

title: Alain Delon: His talent, family conflicts and political views over the years
summary: As Alain Delon's health has recently declined, his three children have begun to fight over his inheritance. 'Le Monde' has long covered Delon, since he was first mentioned in a May 14, 1958, film review.

title: Alpine Ski World Cup: France's Nils Allegre takes first career win
summary: 30-year-old French skier Nils Allegre upset a field of higher-ranked favorites, including season leader Marco Odermatt, to claim his first career World Cup victory in a tight super-G in adverse snow conditions.

title: Hot cocktails to beat cold snaps
summary: The warming power of alcohol is illusory, but some drinks can help you get through the winter chill. Here are five recommendations and the all-important recipes.

title: International Court of Justice calls for protecting Palestinians from genocide
summary: While The Hague's judges stopped short of directing Israel to stop its operations in Gaza, as South Africa had requested, they did require Israel to prevent any acts of genocide and to punish incitement to commit them.

title: Nazi hunter Serge Klarsfeld no longer considers the French far right as an enemy
summary: Klarsfeld has dedicated his life to the memory of the Holocaust and denouncing the then openly anti-Semitic Front National. At 88, the historian now sees the party as an ally against anti-Jewish sentiment and the threat of Islamism.

title: French immigration bill signed into law by Macron
summary: The controversial bill has been revised to remove several measures that were initially introduced under pressure from the right and subsequently censured by France's Constitutional Council.

title: Sweden is moving backward on climate policy
summary: Elected in September 2022, the right-wing and far-right coalition is pursuing a policy that will cause CO2 emissions to rise by 2030 without explaining how it intends to meet its commitments at the European level.

title: Paris 2024: Hotel bookings in Marseille are not taking off for the Games
summary: Hotel professionals are hoping that the two matches involving the French men's football team will boost visitor numbers. The city is counting mainly on the impact of the arrival of the Olympic flame on May 8.

title: United States agrees to negotiate planned troop withdrawal from Iraq
summary: The discussions aim to outline a roadmap and timetable for ending the international coalition's mission against the Islamic State organization.

title: Are American parents making their children's lives miserable?
summary: A long-term study of young Americans shows that, while their relationships with their parents are improving, their overall satisfaction with life is falling. Is this the fault of mom and dad?

title: French farmers unions vow to put Paris under 'indefinite siege' in pay, tax and regulations battle
summary: Farmers from the Lot-et-Garonne, one of the hotspots of the protest movement in southern France, had already announced their intention to 'go to Paris' on Monday.

title: Saudi Arabia opens a door in alcohol prohibition
summary: The first government-run liquor store is due to open soon in Riyadh. Sales will be limited to non-Muslim diplomats, but some see this as a first step towards gradually lifting the ban.

title: Mouthpieces close to the Kremlin announce the arrival of Russian 'military specialists' in Burkina Faso
summary: Ibrahim Traoré's junta continues its rapprochement with the Putin regime. Sources claim that several hundred Russian troops have being deployed in the country.

title: Giorgia Meloni's African ambition
summary: The Italian prime minister is organizing an Italy-Africa summit in Rome, on January 28 and 29. She will on that occasion to present her 'plan for Africa' to cement Italy's role on the continent.

title: Finnish presidential election: Faced with Russia, security takes center stage
summary: Against a backdrop of unprecedented tension with Russia, the Finnish people will vote on January 28 to elect a successor to Sauli Niinistö, president since 2012, who has overseen his country's NATO integration.

title: Israel-Hamas war: What is the UNRWA, and how has it become controversial?
summary: Founded in 1949, this UN agency for Palestinian refugees, an essential lifeline for millions, has seen countries cut their funding to it after some of its employees were accused of involvement in the October 7 attack.

title: Mona Lisa casing splashed with soup by activists in Paris
summary: The famous masterpiece, which hangs in Paris' Louvre museum, has long been targeted by protests, and was damaged in 1956 after a man threw a rock at it. In 2009, its glass casing resisted an empty teacup thrown at it.

title: Salvador Dalí's hideaway, a shack turned sensational palace
summary: Salvador Dalí transformed the fisherman's shack he bought with his wife Gala in Portlligat, Catalonia, into an extraordinary home. It became a museum that photographer Coco Capitán has explored at leisure, immersing herself in the thinking of the surrealist painter, to whom Quentin Dupieux has dedicated a film.

title: Measles is making a worrying comeback in the UK
summary: After an acceleration in the rate of measles infections since the start of the year, the British national health system has launched a vast emergency awareness campaign aimed at 4 million parents.

title: Australian Open: Sinner clinches comeback win over Medvedev in men's final
summary: Italian newcomer Jannik Sinner started the intense final two sets down against Russian third seed Daniil Medvedev, but then powered back over three sets to win his first-ever Grand Slam title.

title: Istanbul Catholic church attacked by armed assailants
summary: The attack, which was committed by two masked men during Sunday mass, killed one man and, according to local authorities, left no wounded. This has prompted officials to view it as a targeted attack on the victim, rather than against the Catholic church.

title: The United States approves the sale of F-16 fighter jets to Turkey after a year of NATO tensions
summary: When Turkey's opposition to Sweden's NATO membership was lifted on January 23, it helped to convince holdouts in the US Senate who had been reluctant to sign an agreement with this unpredictable ally.
